article.title: Angular momentum, mass and charge inequalities for black holes in Einstein-Maxwell gravity with dark matter sector

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Equation (63) describe in the context of Einstein-Maxwell dark matter gravity?
choices: The lower bound on the surface area of a black hole with dark matter.
The upper limit on the charge of a black hole with dark matter.
The relationship between angular momentum and charge in the absence of dark matter.
The lower bound on the mass of a black hole with dark matter.

multiple_choice_question.text: What physical quantity does Amin represent in Equation (84)?
choices: The minimum angular momentum of a dynamical black hole.
The maximum charge of a static black hole.
The minimum surface area of a dynamical black hole.
The total energy of a black hole-dark matter system.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the factor Î³ in Equation (93)?
choices: It represents the gravitational constant in the presence of dark matter.
It accounts for the contribution of both Maxwell and dark matter charges.
It denotes the ratio of dark matter density to ordinary matter density.
It quantifies the strength of the interaction between dark matter and the electromagnetic field.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main implication of Equation (103) regarding black hole formation?
choices: Black holes can only form when the charge density exceeds the mass density.
The presence of dark matter reduces the amount of charge needed to form a black hole.
The formation of black holes is independent of the presence of dark matter.
The presence of dark matter increases the amount of charge needed to form a black hole.
